title: Slope Angle
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of slope angle.

images.caption: Terrain is generally less than 30 degrees
Mostly low angled, isolated areas above 35 degrees
Variable, large percentage greater than 35 degrees

title: Slope shape
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of slope shape.

images.caption: The slope is generally uniform
The slope is convoluted
The slope has some convexities

title: Forest density
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of forest density.

images.caption: Mixed trees and open terrain
Primarily treed with some forest openings
Large expanses of open terrain, isolated tree bands possible

title: Terrain traps
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of terrain traps.

images.caption: Some depressions, gullies and/or overhead avalanche terrain
Minimal, some creek slopes or cutbanks
Many depressions, gullies, cliffs, hidden slopes above gullies, cornices

title: Avalanche frequency
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of avalanche frequency.

images.caption: This terrain could produce avalanches sufficiently large to kill a person
Avalanches sufficiently large to kill a person are rare in this terrain
This terrain regularly produces avalanches sufficiently large to kill a person

title: Start zone density
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of start zone density.

images.caption: Limited open terrain
Some open terrain, isolated avalanche paths leading to valley bottom
Large expanses of open terrain, multiple paths leading to valley bottom

title: Runout zone characteristics
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of runout zone characteristics.

images.caption: Solitary, well defined areas, smooth transitions, spread deposits
Abrupt transitions or depressions with deep deposits
Multiple converging runout zones, confined deposition area, steep tracks overhead

title: Interaction with avalanche paths
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of interaction with avalanche paths.

images.caption: Exposure to runout zones only
Exposure to single path or paths with separation
Exposure to numerous and overlapping paths

title: Route options
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of route options.

images.caption: Numerous; terrain allows multiple choices
A selection of choices of varying exposure; options to avoid avalanche paths
Limited chances to reduce exposure; avoidance not possible

title: Exposure time
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of exposure time.

images.caption: None, or limited exposure crossing runouts only
Isolated exposure to start zones and tracks
Frequent exposure to start zones and tracks

title: Glaciation
desc: In the following exercise there are three images. For each image please select whether the terrain in the image is simple, challenging or complex in terms of glaciation.

images.caption: Generally smooth with isolated bands of crevasses
Broken or steep sections of crevasses, icefalls or serac exposure
No glaciers
